clusters.title: Millions exploited by ‘menopause gold rush’ amid lack of reliable information, say experts
clusters.neutral_headline: Millions exploited by ‘menopause gold rush’ amid lack of reliable information, say experts

items.title: Millions exploited by ‘menopause gold rush’ amid lack of reliable information, say experts
items.standfirst: Women’s health academics at UCL call for education programme to combat misinformation and unregulated adviceMillions of women are being exploited by a “menopause gold rush” as companies, celebrities and influencers take advantage of a “dearth” of reliable information on the issue, experts have said.Healthcare companies and content creators saw menopause as a “lucrative market” and were trying to profit from gaps in public knowledge, women’s health academics at UCL said. Continue reading...
items.content: Women’s health academics at UCL call for education programme to combat misinformation and unregulated adviceMillions of women are being exploited by a “menopause gold rush” as companies, celebrities and influencers take advantage of a “dearth” of reliable information on the issue, experts have said.Healthcare companies and content creators saw menopause as a “lucrative market” and were trying to profit from gaps in public knowledge, women’s health academics at UCL said. Continue reading...

Healthcare companies and content creators are trying to profit from gaps in public knowledge.
The article highlights the exploitation of women during menopause.
The article emphasizes the need for reliable information and education.

clusters.title: Bereaved families call for inquiry into UK failure to act on pro-suicide forum
clusters.neutral_headline: Bereaved families call for inquiry into UK failure to act on pro-suicide forum

items.title: Bereaved families call for inquiry into UK failure to act on pro-suicide forum
items.standfirst: Report found coroners raised concerns over suicide forums at least 65 times to three government departments since 2019Bereaved families and survivors of a pro-suicide forum have called for a public inquiry into the government’s failure to prevent harm linked to the online platform.The calls came as a report found that coroners had raised concerns regarding suicide forums at least 65 times to three government departments since 2019.In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counselor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org Continue reading...
items.content: Report found coroners raised concerns over suicide forums at least 65 times to three government departments since 2019Bereaved families and survivors of a pro-suicide forum have called for a public inquiry into the government’s failure to prevent harm linked to the online platform.The calls came as a report found that coroners had raised concerns regarding suicide forums at least 65 times to three government departments since 2019.In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counselor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org Continue reading...

Coroners raised concerns about suicide forums at least 65 times since 2019.
The report found coroners raised concerns over suicide forums to three government departments.

clusters.title: Keir Starmer pressed not to slash UK contribution to global aid fund
clusters.neutral_headline: Keir Starmer pressed not to slash UK contribution to global aid fund

items.title: Keir Starmer pressed not to slash UK contribution to global aid fund
items.standfirst: Polling finds majority consider £1bn funding for Aids, TB and malaria vaccines a UK success storyPressure is mounting on Keir Starmer not to cut the UK’s contribution to the Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria after polling found 62% of Britons believe the government should maintain or increase its support.The prime minister must decide this year whether to maintain the UK contribution at £1bn or implement a cut in line with recent reductions to the aid budget. A cut of 20% has been rumoured. Continue reading...

A cut of 20% has been rumoured. Continue reading...

clusters.title: The Guardian view on childbirth and medical negligence: rising payouts highlight the urgency of maternity improvements
clusters.neutral_headline: The Guardian view on childbirth and medical negligence: rising payouts highlight the urgency of maternity improvements

items.title: The Guardian view on childbirth and medical negligence: rising payouts highlight the urgency of maternity improvements
items.standfirst: Grave shortcomings in the care offered to mothers and babies are well documented. But it is not clear that the right lessons have been learnedThe startling rise in the cost to the NHS in England of medical negligence cases, and a sharp increase in birth injuries to mothers, are the latest warning signs of deeply troubling failures in maternity services. The £60bn estimate of negligence liabilities, from the National Audit Office, represents a quadrupling in less than 20 years. While some medical specialties have seen falling payouts, those in obstetrics rose. The reason why payments in such negligence cases are so high is that when babies are injured, awards must cover lifetime care needs.Grave shortcomings in maternity care are widely recognised, along with unjust disparities in outcomes for women from different socioeconomic and racial groups. Preventable deaths and injuries at units in Morecambe Bay, Shrewsbury and Telford, and East Kent, have been among the most shocking patient safety scandals of recent years. Continue reading...
items.content: Grave shortcomings in the care offered to mothers and babies are well documented. But it is not clear that the right lessons have been learnedThe startling rise in the cost to the NHS in England of medical negligence cases, and a sharp increase in birth injuries to mothers, are the latest warning signs of deeply troubling failures in maternity services. The £60bn estimate of negligence liabilities, from the National Audit Office, represents a quadrupling in less than 20 years. While some medical specialties have seen falling payouts, those in obstetrics rose. The reason why payments in such negligence cases are so high is that when babies are injured, awards must cover lifetime care needs.Grave shortcomings in maternity care are widely recognised, along with unjust disparities in outcomes for women from different socioeconomic and racial groups. Preventable deaths and injuries at units in Morecambe Bay, Shrewsbury and Telford, and East Kent, have been among the most shocking patient safety scandals of recent years. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Rising payouts in medical negligence cases highlight failures in maternity services.
The cost to the NHS in England of medical negligence cases has quadrupled in 20 years.
Grave shortcomings in maternity care are widely recognized.
Preventable deaths and injuries have occurred in maternity units.
The article emphasizes the need for improvements in maternity services.

clusters.title: Dr Jill Tattersall obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Dr Jill Tattersall obituary: My mother, Jill Tattersall, who has died aged 95, helped to change the face of healthcare by co-founding a clinic providing contraception for unmarried women and underage girls in the 1960s

items.title: Dr Jill Tattersall obituary
items.standfirst: My mother, Jill Tattersall, who has died aged 95, helped to change the face of healthcare by co-founding a clinic providing contraception for unmarried women and underage girls in the 1960s.She qualified as a doctor in Sheffield in 1956 and started out by training in obstetrics and gynaecology, quickly moving into the new field of family planning. During the 60s, birth control supplied by the NHS was only for married women and there was still a great deal of stigma attached to premarital sex and underage relationships. Continue reading...
items.content: My mother, Jill Tattersall, who has died aged 95, helped to change the face of healthcare by co-founding a clinic providing contraception for unmarried women and underage girls in the 1960s.She qualified as a doctor in Sheffield in 1956 and started out by training in obstetrics and gynaecology, quickly moving into the new field of family planning. During the 60s, birth control supplied by the NHS was only for married women and there was still a great deal of stigma attached to premarital sex and underage relationships. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Dr. Jill Tattersall, who died at 95, co-founded a clinic for contraception.
The clinic provided contraception for unmarried women and underage girls in the 1960s.
She qualified as a doctor in Sheffield in 1956 and trained in obstetrics and gynecology.
Birth control was only for married women, and stigma surrounded premarital sex.
The obituary highlights her contributions to healthcare and family planning.

clusters.title: Why men should be doing a lot more pilates | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Pilates Benefits for Men Highlighted in Articles

items.title: Why men should be doing a lot more pilates | Letters
items.standfirst: Tim Heavisides hails the benefits of pilates for rugby players, and Margaret Evans highlights the knee-injuries sustained in walking football I was very pleased to read George Ford’s “confession” that “in recent months I’ve been doing a lot more pilates” (George Ford turns down R360 riches for last shot at England World Cup glory, 15 October).In the last six years, so have I, and I wish that I’d discovered pilates 50 years ago when I was playing rugby; I’m sure I would have recovered more quickly from injuries and maintained a higher level of fitness with a much stronger “core”, so essential in such a physical sport. Continue reading...
items.content: Tim Heavisides hails the benefits of pilates for rugby players, and Margaret Evans highlights the knee-injuries sustained in walking football I was very pleased to read George Ford’s “confession” that “in recent months I’ve been doing a lot more pilates” (George Ford turns down R360 riches for last shot at England World Cup glory, 15 October).In the last six years, so have I, and I wish that I’d discovered pilates 50 years ago when I was playing rugby; I’m sure I would have recovered more quickly from injuries and maintained a higher level of fitness with a much stronger “core”, so essential in such a physical sport. Continue reading...

One article mentions a rugby player incorporating pilates into his training regimen.
Another article highlights the potential for quicker injury recovery through pilates.
Stronger core muscles, essential in physical sports, are a key benefit.
The author wishes they had discovered pilates earlier in their rugby career.

clusters.title: Smart jab can shrink head and neck cancer tumours within six weeks, trial finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Smart Jab Shrinks Cancer Tumors in Trial

items.title: Smart jab can shrink head and neck cancer tumours within six weeks, trial finds
items.standfirst: Triple-action therapy drug amivantamab could be given as an injection to help treat recurrent or metastatic cancersDoctors have hailed “incredibly encouraging” trial results that show a triple-action smart jab can shrink tumours in head and neck cancer patients within six weeks.Head and neck cancer is the world’s sixth most common form of the disease. If it spreads or comes back after standard treatment, patients may be offered immunotherapy and platinum chemotherapy. But if this fails, there is often little else doctors can do. Continue reading...
items.content: Triple-action therapy drug amivantamab could be given as an injection to help treat recurrent or metastatic cancersDoctors have hailed “incredibly encouraging” trial results that show a triple-action smart jab can shrink tumours in head and neck cancer patients within six weeks.Head and neck cancer is the world’s sixth most common form of the disease. If it spreads or comes back after standard treatment, patients may be offered immunotherapy and platinum chemotherapy. But if this fails, there is often little else doctors can do. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A triple-action therapy drug, amivantamab, is given as an injection.
The drug is used to treat recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancers.
Trial results show tumor shrinkage in head and neck cancer patients within six weeks.
Head and neck cancer is the world's sixth most common form of the disease.
Standard treatments may include immunotherapy and platinum chemotherapy.

clusters.title: The lavender marriage is back – but why? | Emma Beddington
clusters.neutral_headline: The Lavender Marriage is Back, But Why?

items.title: The lavender marriage is back – but why? | Emma Beddington
items.standfirst: People are taking many new and unexpected approaches to matrimony, and it is surprisingly excitingThe lavender marriage – that administrative convenience and PR fiction of golden age Hollywood – is back. The Washington Post recently covered its reinvention, meeting Jacob Hoff, who’s gay, and Samantha Greenstone, who’s straight, a blissfully married couple with a baby on the way (they “birds’d and bees’d” Greenstone explained for the pruriently curious). The Post also spoke to friends April Lexi Lee and Sheree Wong, both “on the asexual spectrum”, who say they “bestied so hard we got married … platonically”.Of course, if you’re talking openly about a lavender marriage, it isn’t one. The point of them was to confer a fig leaf of heteronormative respectability at a time when that was professionally and socially essential; these people aren’t in it for appearances. Hoff and Greenstone don’t like the term: “It cheapens what we really have, which is a love match,” Greenstone says. But “lavender marriage” has been co-opted online as a shorthand for different forms of loving, committed relationships that do not centre conventional romance and sexual desire, both as jokey aspiration and lived experience. They need another name: some people call themselves platonic life partners (PLPs); I’ve seen “rainbow marriage” on TikTok.Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...
items.content: People are taking many new and unexpected approaches to matrimony, and it is surprisingly excitingThe lavender marriage – that administrative convenience and PR fiction of golden age Hollywood – is back. The Washington Post recently covered its reinvention, meeting Jacob Hoff, who’s gay, and Samantha Greenstone, who’s straight, a blissfully married couple with a baby on the way (they “birds’d and bees’d” Greenstone explained for the pruriently curious). The Post also spoke to friends April Lexi Lee and Sheree Wong, both “on the asexual spectrum”, who say they “bestied so hard we got married … platonically”.Of course, if you’re talking openly about a lavender marriage, it isn’t one. The point of them was to confer a fig leaf of heteronormative respectability at a time when that was professionally and socially essential; these people aren’t in it for appearances. Hoff and Greenstone don’t like the term: “It cheapens what we really have, which is a love match,” Greenstone says. But “lavender marriage” has been co-opted online as a shorthand for different forms of loving, committed relationships that do not centre conventional romance and sexual desire, both as jokey aspiration and lived experience. They need another name: some people call themselves platonic life partners (PLPs); I’ve seen “rainbow marriage” on TikTok.Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the resurgence of "lavender marriages" in modern society.
It explores different forms of committed relationships that are not traditionally romantic.
The term "lavender marriage" is used to describe these non-conventional relationships.
Some couples prefer the term "platonic life partners" or "rainbow marriage".
The article seeks opinions on the issues raised regarding these relationships.

clusters.title: Inside the Republican network behind big soda’s bid to pit Maga against Maha
clusters.neutral_headline: Soda Industry Campaign Targets RFK Jr's Movement

items.title: Inside the Republican network behind big soda’s bid to pit Maga against Maha
items.standfirst: A Guardian investigation finds the US soda and snack-food industries, threatened by RFK Jr’s movement to change Americans’ eating habits, have turned to a group of well-connected strategists, shadowy pollsters and ‘anti-woke’ influencersMajor US soft-drink and snack-food corporations are waging a coordinated campaign that aims to pit Donald Trump’s Maga faithful against Robert F Kennedy Jr’s Make America Healthy Again movement, a Guardian investigation in partnership with environmental watchdog Fieldnotes has found. Their goal is to stymie the Maha-led effort to curb Americans’ consumption of soda and ultra-processed foods.To carry out the plan, the companies have turned to a partially formalized network of for-hire pollsters, strategists and political financiers with deep ties to the national Republican party – several of whom have taken steps that obscure their connection to the effort and to one another. In the process, the industry has also been aided less directly by a loose coalition of free-market ideologues who have previously worked to advance Trump’s deregulatory agenda. Continue reading...
items.content: A Guardian investigation finds the US soda and snack-food industries, threatened by RFK Jr’s movement to change Americans’ eating habits, have turned to a group of well-connected strategists, shadowy pollsters and ‘anti-woke’ influencersMajor US soft-drink and snack-food corporations are waging a coordinated campaign that aims to pit Donald Trump’s Maga faithful against Robert F Kennedy Jr’s Make America Healthy Again movement, a Guardian investigation in partnership with environmental watchdog Fieldnotes has found. Their goal is to stymie the Maha-led effort to curb Americans’ consumption of soda and ultra-processed foods.To carry out the plan, the companies have turned to a partially formalized network of for-hire pollsters, strategists and political financiers with deep ties to the national Republican party – several of whom have taken steps that obscure their connection to the effort and to one another. In the process, the industry has also been aided less directly by a loose coalition of free-market ideologues who have previously worked to advance Trump’s deregulatory agenda. Continue reading...

ai_summary: US soda and snack-food industries are fighting RFK Jr's health movement.
The industries aim to counter efforts to change Americans' eating habits.
They are using a network of strategists and pollsters with Republican ties.
The industry is aided by free-market ideologues who support deregulation.
The goal is to curb consumption of soda and ultra-processed foods.

clusters.title: Chemical linked to low sperm count, obesity and cancer found in dummies, tests find
clusters.neutral_headline: Chemical Found in Dummies Linked to Health Issues

items.title: Chemical linked to low sperm count, obesity and cancer found in dummies, tests find
items.standfirst: BPA, a synthetic chemical used in production of plastics, found in baby products made by three big European brandsA chemical linked to impaired sexual development, obesity and cancer has been found in baby dummies manufactured by three big European brands.Dummies made by the Dutch multinational Philips, the Swiss oral health specialists Curaprox and the French toy brand Sophie la Girafe were found to contain bisphenol A (BPA), according to laboratory testing by dTest, a Czech consumer organisation. Philips said they had carried out subsequent testing and found no BPA, while Sophie la Girafe said the amount found was insignificant. Continue reading...
items.content: BPA, a synthetic chemical used in production of plastics, found in baby products made by three big European brandsA chemical linked to impaired sexual development, obesity and cancer has been found in baby dummies manufactured by three big European brands.Dummies made by the Dutch multinational Philips, the Swiss oral health specialists Curaprox and the French toy brand Sophie la Girafe were found to contain bisphenol A (BPA), according to laboratory testing by dTest, a Czech consumer organisation. Philips said they had carried out subsequent testing and found no BPA, while Sophie la Girafe said the amount found was insignificant. Continue reading...

ai_summary: BPA, a chemical, was found in baby dummies from European brands.
The chemical is linked to low sperm count, obesity, and cancer.
The brands include Philips, Curaprox, and Sophie la Girafe.
Subsequent testing by Philips found no BPA in their products.
Sophie la Girafe stated the amount found was insignificant.

clusters.title: Thousands of new mothers in England readmitted to hospital after birth, figures show
clusters.neutral_headline: Thousands of Mothers Readmitted to Hospital After Birth

items.title: Thousands of new mothers in England readmitted to hospital after birth, figures show
items.standfirst: Exclusive: More than 14,600 women readmitted within 30 days of birth in last year, raising alarm over early dischargesThousands of new mothers are being readmitted to hospital in England every year, figures reveal, raising fresh concerns about NHS maternity care.Discharging women from hospital prematurely increases the risk of conditions linked to childbirth being missed, and can be extremely distressing. If childbirth injuries or other conditions are not treated until the mother is readmitted days or weeks later, the chances of a complete recovery may also be reduced. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: More than 14,600 women readmitted within 30 days of birth in last year, raising alarm over early dischargesThousands of new mothers are being readmitted to hospital in England every year, figures reveal, raising fresh concerns about NHS maternity care.Discharging women from hospital prematurely increases the risk of conditions linked to childbirth being missed, and can be extremely distressing. If childbirth injuries or other conditions are not treated until the mother is readmitted days or weeks later, the chances of a complete recovery may also be reduced. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Thousands of new mothers are readmitted to hospitals in England.
Over 14,600 women were readmitted within 30 days of birth.
The figures raise concerns about NHS maternity care practices.
Early discharges increase the risk of missed conditions.
Delayed treatment can reduce the chances of complete recovery.

clusters.title: Beyond chicken soup: what chefs and doctors eat when they’re sick (or just hungover)
clusters.neutral_headline: Chefs and Doctors Share Sick Day Food Choices

items.title: Beyond chicken soup: what chefs and doctors eat when they’re sick (or just hungover)
items.standfirst: Laid up with the flu? Suffering with a sore throat? From chicken bhuna to fire honey, this food should get you back on your feetHydrate with teas For Dr Ricardo José, consultant in respiratory medicine, hydration is key: “It’s about taking frequent sips throughout the day to keep the mucous membranes moist.” Immunologist Dr Jenna Macciochi agrees, saying: “I often stir a spoonful of raw honey – nature’s soothing antimicrobial – into a cup of thyme tea (thyme steeped in water), which helps ease irritation and supports respiratory health. I also love marshmallow root tea, which is great for the mucous membranes.” Continue reading...
items.content: Laid up with the flu? Suffering with a sore throat? From chicken bhuna to fire honey, this food should get you back on your feetHydrate with teas For Dr Ricardo José, consultant in respiratory medicine, hydration is key: “It’s about taking frequent sips throughout the day to keep the mucous membranes moist.” Immunologist Dr Jenna Macciochi agrees, saying: “I often stir a spoonful of raw honey – nature’s soothing antimicrobial – into a cup of thyme tea (thyme steeped in water), which helps ease irritation and supports respiratory health. I also love marshmallow root tea, which is great for the mucous membranes.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article explores food choices for when people are sick or hungover.
It features recommendations from chefs and medical professionals.
Hydration is emphasized as a key factor in recovery.
Honey and thyme tea are suggested for soothing sore throats.
Marshmallow root tea is recommended for mucous membranes.
